Peter was not altogether incapable of appreciating the more deli- cate charm of the company of women, and Russian feminine society was one of his first creations. On the whole however he preferred servant girls or similar typeS. Such was Catherine, his second wife, who had begun her career by wandering from camp to camp at the disposal of the soldiers and officers of her future consort.

The brother of Anna Mons, william, was accused later of having had relations with Catherine, and was executed. After the execution Peter passed the scaffold in a sledge together with Catherine and 50 61056 that her robes touched the body of her alleged lover. When the Czarine appeared unmoved by the sight, Peter had the severed head of William Mons preserved in alcohol placed in her apartments. Many years afterward a commission appointed to investigate the consumption of spirits in the imperial household discovered two vessels in the cellars of the castle containing the heads of a former mistress of Czar Peter and of W'jlliam Mons, which preserved their pristine beauty. The heads were buried in the vaults of the castle by command of Cath- erine II.
